Description: Body and base sherd of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black; traces of frieze of petals in added white and red between pairs of narrow bands in white; below on bottom of bowl, second frieze of petals in white and red; exterior: part of two bands (fired brown).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Ure Museum of Greek Archaeology, Reading. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos identifies the sherd as belonging to a phiale mesomphalos, however, the shape of the sherd is too conical for a phiale and the bottom of the sherd clearly indicated that a foot was once attached; phialai do not have feet. The Ure Museum received sherds from the Egypt Exploration Society (EES) in 1926, several years after Petrie and Gardner's excavations. It was uncertain then whether the sherds came from Naukratis or Tell Dafana, a site in the eastern Nile Delta that was excavated by Petrie in 1886. Petrie wrote that he found only one sherd of Chian ware at Tell Dafana (Petrie 1888 62), which he described as a plain piece, thus the Chian sherds in the Reading collection come from Naukratis.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 306, no. 1226, pl. 159)
CVA Reading I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain, Fasc. 12, University of Reading (p. 38, pl. 23, no. 10a-b)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1213) (phase 2)
